data.title: Search shows results for the same file twice if it's open as a differently-cased filename
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

I'm not sure if it can be easily reproduced using plain VS Code, but if some extension screws up the file name case in e.g. a "definition provider", this will happen: https://github.com/hackwaly/vscode-ocaml/issues/56

Looks like file paths are used as keys somewhere and they are not normalized or something. Maybe it's not just search, but also other places.

data.title: Show folder name prefix in tab if multiple files are having the same name
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: OS X

![screen shot 2016-09-06 at 3 13 54 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/543633/18292905/aff285be-7444-11e6-943e-22f585d1c512.png)

It's a common pattern in many projects to have an `index` file in each folder. When I open multiple index files I can't tell from tab header which index file is which. 

To fix this problem I'm proposing to have a smarter tab name that detects if multiple tabs are having exact same file name and prepends the folder those files are at in the tab header. It should do this when multiple editor instances of the same file are open.

data.title: Show high-contrast hover cursor on integrated terminal on Mac. Fix #11129
Typescript 2.0.2: Global Types Not Found if tsconfig.json Contains an "include" Field
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

I am using typescript 2.0.2 and installing types with npm.

I have the following `tsconfig.json`:

``` json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "module": "commonjs",
    "target": "es6",
    "moduleResolution": "node",
    "baseUrl": "src",
    "allowSyntheticDefaultImports": true,
    "noImplicitAny": true,
    "sourceMap": true,
    "outDir": "ts-build",
    "jsx": "react",
    "types": ["mocha", "node"]
  },
  "include": [
    "src"
  ],
  "files": [
    "type-declarations/globals.d.ts"
  ]
}
```

If the `include` field is present, then my global types (`mocha` / `node` / types defined in `globals.d.ts`) are not found by vscode (see pic below):
![screen shot 2016-09-07 at 00 02 24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6689924/18292604/61eaef38-748e-11e6-8d67-fa1dcb3526ae.png)

If I remove the `include` field then vscode finds the global types, but my webpack rebuilds often fail due to out of memory errors.

Running `tsc` or webpack with `ts-loader` does not produce any errors with the above config.

Running `tsc` with `"includeFiles": true` in the `tsconfig.json` produces the following output:

```
/Users/david/Code/typescript-boilerplate/node_modules/typescript/lib/lib.es6.d.ts
/Users/david/Code/typescript-boilerplate/type-declarations/globals.d.ts
/Users/david/Code/typescript-boilerplate/node_modules/@types/mocha/index.d.ts
/Users/david/Code/typescript-boilerplate/node_modules/@types/node/index.d.ts
```

You can see the full project here: https://github.com/xwvvvvwx/typescript-react-electron-boilerplate

Am I missing something?

data.title: File search popup disappears when tabbing away from code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0-insider (538cd9ded5a471fbb20920f01eff9c8df4b83ee9)
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6 (15G1004)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press Cmd-P
2. Start searching for a file you haven't yet searched for in a large project (the file doesn't even have to exist - I just did 'asdf' to verify)
3. Cmd-Tab away to another app
4. Cmd-Tab back to code
5. Your Cmd-P search has disappeared and (to all appearances) been canceled.

This is especially frustrating given it can sometimes take near a minute for results on large projects (I'm working on https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central) and I would like to be able to tab away from code to finish reading the bug I'm working on while it searches the files. As it stands, I have to just wait for code to finish searching.

data.title: Handle undefined terminal name. Fix #11397
Provide a way to remove a CodeLens in the resolveCodeLens
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.5.0-insider (1.5.0-insider)` 538cd9ded5a471fbb20920f01eff9c8df4b83ee9
- OS Version: `OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.6 (15G31)`

Sometimes you want the work to ultimately show a CodeLens to be deferred as much as possible, so it would be create if there was a way to signal that CodeLens being resolve isn't actually desired anymore.

For example, it might be desirable to not show a "references" CodeLens if there are no references (rather than having to say 'no references' or something like that). Basically for any CodeLens where the work involved in actually resolving it is too expensive in the providing phase.

data.title: Add line-wrap to file comparison

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Currently, there is no way to wrap long lines when comparing two files. Alt+Z has no effect, the "Softwrap" plugin has no effect, nothing. This makes it extremely cumbersome to compare using files that have long lines.

data.title: Support multiple-indent levels for onEnterRules/IndentActions
data.body:
I don't know whether this functionality would be useful to any language except Dart, so I understand if you don't want to add this, but I thought it was worth asking (it's also a place for others to add comments if it was somehow useful for them!)

Dart has some weird rules around multi-line statements - they should be intended "twice". Normally indenting in Dart is 2-spaces but multi-line statements get 4 spaces. eg:

``` dart
test() {
  ["a", "b"]
      .where((iiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii) =>
          iiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii != null)
      .sort();
}
```

Since we can't currently support formatOnType (the Dart formatter can't do partial docs) I hoped to use the indent rules to achieve this, but I would need to be able to indent twice and this is not currently supported.

Adding support for multiple-indent levels to `IndentationRule` and/or `OnEnterRule` would probably allow this (though again, this seems like it might be a very Dart-specific request).

data.title: Extensions should be able to define code folding regions in a document

data.title: Markdown links that are indented 2 lines in a list are not highlighted
data.body: - VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.5.0-insider (06d85431730fe33beff7c56b5ef6f4514ad326ba, 2016-08-09T16:02:06.523Z) - OS Version: Darwin x64 14.5.0 Interestingly it only happens on the second line after a list.

data.title: Add Seti theme
Provide guidance to language and extension authors
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.5.0-insider (1.5.0-insider)` 538cd9ded5a471fbb20920f01eff9c8df4b83ee9
- OS Version: `OS X El Capitan Version 10.11.6 (15G31)`

Given the power of the abstractions that vscode provides for symbols, definitions, references, etc, I think it would be great if there was some guidance (best practices) documentation on how a language _should_ provide the information. For example, when implementing a `DocumentSymbolProvider` what should the range be of the symbol? TypeScript/JavaScript/JSON seem to include the body of a symbol (that has one), where as C# (Omnisharp) only provides a range covering just the keyword alone. Which one is _right_ or more accurately which one is provides more to build upon and should be considered the better practice.

Also along the same lines -- there is a LOT of power in the `vscode.executeDocumentSymbolProvider`, `vscode.executeReferenceProvider`, and others, but from the documentation I don't think it is really clear. For example, utilizing both `vscode.executeDocumentSymbolProvider` and `vscode.executeReferenceProvider` together, once should be able to create a single extension to provide usage CodeLens support for any language that supports those providers -- without the need of every language adding that type of support.

Thoughts?

data.title: Launcher node js don't work anymore since last apple update
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:41:29.513Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.6.0
- OSX el Capitan 10.11.6 (15G1004)
  Steps to Reproduce:
1.  set the lauch.json with this json : 

``` json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Lancer",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/index.js",
            "stopOnEntry": false,
            "args": [],
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            /*"preLaunchTask": "test",*/
            "runtimeExecutable": null,
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "--nolazy"
            ],
            "env": {
                "NODE_ENV": "development"
            },
            "externalConsole": false,
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null
        },
        {
            "name": "Attacher",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "port": 5858,
            "address": "localhost",
            "restart": false,
            "sourceMaps": false,
            "outDir": null,
            "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "remoteRoot": null
        }
    ]
}
```
1. click on F5 to launch the debugger.
2. Try to ping your node application ( on my computer, port localhost:3000 )

The node application does not respond anymore, but if i use "node index.js" in the folder with the index.js file, the application is working well.
This issue appeared when i installed the last update of OSX el Capitan ( just before it it was working well).

data.title: Joh/11455

data.title: Node apps do not terminate in debug mode
External Terminal support for runInTerminal request
data.body:
Move the code that manages external terminals from the node-debug plugin into the VS Code execution service and surface it as a `runInTerminal` API.
Make it configurable via the configuration service.

data.title: [typescript] use the language service for tokenization

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
There is too many [issues](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript-TmLanguage/issues) with the TM grammar, many of which seem to be impossible to fix.

E.g. in Microsoft/TypeScript-TmLanguage#121, we can read this:

> I think it's possible that this might never be completely fixed, due to limitations of the textmate grammar system.

Isn't it better to try another approach (the one that Visual Studio uses) instead of trying to fix the unfixable?
